p: DGGE profiles showed that the AMF composition differed in invasive S. canadensis versus native K. striata. AC affected the pattern and signal intensity of bands of the 18S rDNA fragments of AMF in roots of S. canadensis and K. striata ( Fig. S1). The phylogenetic analysis indicated that sequences retrieved from all root samples could be separated into six AMF groups (GA1â€“GA6) ( Fig. S2). AC treatments affected AMF phylotypes in S. canadensis roots but not in K. striata roots ( Fig. 1C). Roots of S. canadensis were colonized by five AMF phylotypes when AC was not added (group GA4 was missing) and by four phylotypes when AC was added (GA2 and GA5 were missing) ( Fig. 1C). AMF phylotypes GA1, GA3, and GA6 in roots of S. canadensis or K. striata were not affected by the addition of AC ( Fig. 1C).
